Table 2 Samples κ (mol/gcat h) α (mmol/g) t1/2 (h) R0 (gMeOH/gcat) TC (mgcoke/gcat) AC (mgcoke/gcat h) ZC1 11.4 246.1 6.6 45.4 110.9 15.1 ZC3 4.9 38.7 41.8 288.6 142.1 3.9 ZC4 21.5 97.5 16.6 114.5 119.3 6.9 ZC5 3.4 274.7 5.9 40.7 64.8 10.2 ZC5-at 2.9 195.9 8.2 56.7 138.2 14.8 One-step synthesis of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolites with low defect density as long-lived MTH catalysts Meng Pan Conceptualization Methodology Writing – original draft a ⁎ Xianbang Jiang Formal analysis Investigation Data curation a Yahui Pang Validation a Xianfeng Pan Investigation a Qihang Zhang Investigation a Renchun Yang Supervision, Writing – review and editing a ⁎ Jiajun Zheng Resources b a School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Anhui Polytechnic University, Wuhu 241000, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Anhui Polytechnic University Wuhu 241000 China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Anhui Polytechnic University, Wuhu 241000, China b Research Centre of Catalysis & Chemical Technology for Energy, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China Research Centre of Catalysis & Chemical Technology for Energy, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China Research Centre of Catalysis & Chemical Technology for Energy, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China ⁎ Correspondence to: School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Anhui Polytechnic University, No. 8, Beijing Middle Road, Wuhu 241000, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Anhui Polytechnic University No. 8, Beijing Middle Road Wuhu 241000 China The combination of introducing mesopores and minimizing framework defects in zeolite catalysts has been proved to be highly effective in improving their catalytic lifetime in the MTH reaction. However, there is currently a lack of simple method to realize these two purposes at the same time. In this work, we report a simple one-step approach which not only completed the introduction of abundant mesopores into zeolite catalyst but also simultaneously realized the reduction of framework defects. Secondary template, fluoride media and post-treatment technology were not used during the synthetic process. As an example, a hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst with low defect density was successfully synthesized. In the MTH reaction, the synergy effect of the hierarchical pore structure and the less framework defects endowed the prepared zeolite catalyst with a very long lifetime, which is 7.1 times that of the reference catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Zeolite Hierarchical pore Defect sites MTH Long-lived catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the crude oil being depleting, the production of industrial chemicals (such as olefins and aromatics) and liquid fuels is facing increasing challenges [1]. Against this background, seeking for alternative approachs to manufacturing these products has attracted interest from numerous researches [2–4]. Among several alternatives, methanol to hydrocarbons (MTH) process which mainly produces olefins as well as gasoline-range hydrocarbons is regarded as a promising way because methanol can be mass-produced from many resources with rich reserves, such as natural gas, coal, shale gas and even biomass [4]. The MTH process was developed in the 1970 s and has been studied for decades [5]. However, it still suffers from many problems at present, limiting its widespread application [6–8]. The fast deactivation rate of the catalyst is one of the most important problems [3]. In general, the frequent regeneration of the catalyst can cause a significant increase in operating cost [9]. Therefore, it is vital to investigate how to improve the lifetime of the MTH catalyst [10,11]. ZSM-5 zeolite is a commonly used catalyst in the MTH process [12]. The deactivation of this catalyst is mainly attributed to the formation of coke [13]. Many reports indicate that the rapid deactivation rate is closely correlated with the diffusion limitation coming from the sole micropores [14–16]. In this view, the difficulties in the mass transport of the generated hydrocarbon species facilitate the deposition of coke precursors [13]. Moreover, the micropores can be easily blocked by the deposited coke, which further prevents the reactants from accessing the active sites [17]. Fortunately, it has been proved that the diffusion limitation can be circumvented by introducing meso- and/or macropores into zeolite crystals, i.e. constructing hierarchical zeolites [18]. Thus, a lot of researchers have tried to prolong the lifetime of MTH catalyst by engineering hierarchical pore structures in recent decade [19–21]. For example, Yu et al. [21] prepared a single-crystalline ZSM-5 zeolite with highly open nano architectures and hierarchical porosities which exhibits a remarkably enhanced catalytic lifetime and a low coking rate in the MTH reaction. So far, a series of achievements have been made in the field of hierarchical zeolites [22]. In particular, numerous synthetic methods have been established, including dieselization, dealumination, templating method, kinetic regulation and so on [23]. Undoubtedly, these achievements have greatly promoted the progress of MTH catalyst. On the other hand, the internal framework defects in zeolite crystals also have a significant impact on the deactivation of MTH catalyst [24–26]. Valtchev et al. [27] suggested that these defects are probably capacious enough to accommodate the coke precursors, such as bulky penta- and hexamethylbenzene species, which cann’t escape through the microporous channels and then evolve into coke during the MTH reaction. Moreover, the defect sites usually result in the formation of internal silanols, interacting OH groups, perturbed framework Al atoms and Al-Lewis sites [25]. Thibault-Starzyk et al. [28] have demonstrated that the coke species are mainly deposited on the non-acidic silanol groups in zeolite crystals. In short, the framework defects in zeolite crystals can promote the formation of coke and thus will accelerate the deactivation of MTH catalyst [24]. Thus, decreasing the content of defect sites is a great approach to suppress the coke deposition and prolong the catalytic lifetime [29]. However, there are not many present methods for reducing the framework defects in zeolite crystals and nearly all of them involve the use of fluoride media [26,27,29,30]. In view of the dangers of fluorine pollution, the new environment-friendly approaches are highly desired. It should be noted that the introduction of meso- and/or macropores into zeolite crystals may cause the increase of framework defects. For example, the hierarchical H-ZSM-5 synthesized by using carbon particles exhibited higher content of defect sites than the corresponding microporous sample [25]. In addition, removing the framework defects in hierarchical zeolites usually involves the complicated post-treatment procedures [29–31]. Thus, establishing a simple and environment-friendly method which can realize the introduction of mesopores and the minimization of defect sites in zeolites at the same time is of great significant to develop the long-lived MTH catalyst. Recently, we reported a facile method for preparing hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolites, in which the crystallization kinetics was regulated only by changing the added amount of NaOH in the initial synthesis gel [32]. Herein, this novel method was further modified. The modified approach not only completed the introduction of abundant mesopores into ZSM-5 zeolite but also realized the reduction of framework defects. More importantly, it didn’t involve the use of fluoride media and post-treatment technology. To the best of our knowledge, such a simple approach that can accomplish the above two goals at the same time has not been reported in the previous literatures. Benefiting from the hierarchical pore structure and the less framework defects, the prepared hierarchical zeolite catalyst exhibited a significantly prolonged catalytic lifetime in the MTH reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPABr, 98 wt%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96 wt%), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl, 99.5 wt%) and methanol (99.5 wt%) were purchased from Macklin. Sodium aluminate (NaAlO2, 41 wt% of Al2O3, 35 wt% of Na2O) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Silica sol (30 wt%) was purchased from Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without any purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts with different pore structures were synthesized with a composition of x Na2O: 80 SiO2: 1 Al2O3: 8.5 TPABr: 1809 H2O, where x = 1.4 − 17.2. Typically, 0.55 g of NaAlO2, 0 − 2.8 g of NaOH and 5.0 g of TPABr were added into 42 mL of deionized water. After complete dissolution of the solids, 30 mL of silica sol was added into the solution under vigorous stirring. The mixtures were stirred for another 2 h at room temperature to form a gel and then transferred into Teflon-lined autoclaves to crystallization at 180 ℃ for 72 h. The solid products were recovered by filtrating, washed with deionized water and dried at 90 ℃ overnight. In order to remove the organic templates in the cages and the pore channels, the solid products were then calcined in air at 550 ℃ for 6 h. The NH4 + form samples were obtained by ion exchange for three times with 1.0 M NH4Cl aqueous solution at 60 ℃ for 2 h at each time. The H-form catalysts were then obtained by calcining the NH4 + form samples at 550 ℃ for 4 h and denoted as ZCm. ZC0, ZC1, ZC2, ZC3, ZC4, ZC5 and ZC6 represent the catalysts synthesized by adding 0 g, 0.4 g, 0.8 g, 1.3 g, 1.7 g, 2.2 g and 2.8 g of NaOH in the initial synthesis gel respectively. For comparison, an alkaline treatment was carried out on the NH4 + form ZC5 sample according to the literature. The treatment temperature was 65 ℃ and the duration was 30 min. The alkaline-treated sample was then converted into the H-form catalyst by the aforementioned NH4 + ion exchange followed by calcination at 550 ℃ for 5 h and denoted as ZC5-at. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts XRD patterns of the catalysts were recorded using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu-Kα radiation and operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The relative crystallinity was determined from the total areas of the peaks located at 7.9°, 8.8°, 23.0°, 23.2°, 23.6°, 23.9° and 24.3° using the commercial ZC5 as reference. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Shimazdu FTIR-8400 spectrometer in KBr pellets. FT-IR spectra in the OH-stretching region were collected on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific). A self-supporting wafer consisting of 15 mg of the catalyst was placed in a lab-made in situ IR cell equipped with a CaF2 window and online vacuum system. The wafer was degassed at 500 ℃ for 4 h under vacuum. SEM images were carried out with a Hitachi S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope. N2 adsorption-desorption measurements were performed at − 196 ℃ on a NOVA 1200e gas sorption analyzer and Ar adsorption-desorption measurements were conducted at − 186 ℃ on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Before the measurements, the catalysts were degassed under vacuum for 4 h at 300 ℃. TEM images were carried out with a JEOL JEM-200CX transmission electron microscope coupled with a selected area electron diffraction (SAED). The bulk Si/Al ratios of the catalysts were obtained using an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (PANalytical Axios). 29Si and 27Al MAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DSX 300 spectrometer. The framework Si/Al ratios were estimated from the peak intensity of different sites in the 29Si MAS NMR spectra using the method reported by Wu et al. [33]. 1H MAS NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE Ⅲ HD 400 MHz spectrometer using 4 mm rotor. Before the measurements, the catalysts were dehydrated at 400 ℃ for 12 h under vacuum. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was carried out on a TP-5076 apparatus equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. First, 100 mg of catalyst was loaded in a quartz tube. Then, it was treated at 550 ℃ for 2 h in a highly purified He (99.999%) flow. After being cooled down to 120 ℃, the sample was saturated with a NH3 (5%)/He gas mixture, followed by being purged with the highly purified He at 120 ℃ for an hour. Then, the temperature was increased with a rate of 10 ℃/min and the NH3 desorption was monitored in a highly purified He flow (30 mL/min). In this experiment, a gas dryer was set up between the catalyst and the TCD to avoid the influence of water. The acid concentration of the catalyst was calculated from the peak area compared to a standard peak area of 1 mL of NH3 based on the curve. The peak below 350 ℃ is assigned to weak acid and the peak above 350 ℃ corresponds to strong acid. 2.4 Catalytic reaction (MTH) The MTH reaction was conducted at atmospheric pressure using nitrogen as carrier gas in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor. Prior to the experiment, the catalysts were made into 20 − 40 mesh catalyst particles, followed by being activated under a N2 flowing of 30 mL/min at 550 ℃ for 2 h. The loading amount of catalyst was 0.2 g. Then the reactor temperature was decreased to 420 ℃. Methanol was fed into the reactor by a micro-pump and the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was kept at 6.9 h−1. The flow rate of N2 carrier was 30 mL/min and the lines were kept over 200 ℃ using heating tapes. All of the products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Agilent GC6890, FID detector, HP-Plot-Q capillary column). It’s worth noting that dimethyl ether was considered as reactant and added to methanol amount in the calculation of conversion and selectivity. The methanol conversion as a function of time-on-stream was fitted with the deactivation model proposed by Janssens [34]: X = (exp(κτ0)− 1)exp(−καt)/(1 +(exp(κτ0)− 1)exp(−καt))× 100%, where X is a methanol conversion, τ0 is an initial contact time, κ is a rate constant and α is a deactivation coefficient. The catalytic lifetime (t1/2) was defined as the time at which the catalytic conversion decreased by 50%. The maximum amount of methanol that can be converted per gram catalyst is referred to as the conversion capacity (R0) which was calculated according to the equation: R0 = WHSV·t1/2. 2.5 Analysis of coke deposition After the reactions, the total amount of coke in the catalysts was analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) using a TGA N-1000 instrument (Thermo). The coke formation inside micropores (internal coke) was calculated from the decrease in the micropore volume determined by N2 adsorption-desorption measurement, assuming the coke density of 1.22 g/cm3 [29]. The coke content deposited on the external surface was calculated by subtracting the internal coke content from the total coke content determined by TGA. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of hierarchical zeolite catalysts Consistent with our previous study [32], the ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts with high crystallinity can be prepared within a certain concentration range of NaOH in the synthesis gel, as shown in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Material. When the concentration of NaOH is too high or too low, the resultant product is or contains largely an amorphous phase. Table 1 shows that the relative crystallinities of the catalysts ZC1 to ZC5 are very close, all exceed 90%. Moreover, the catalyst ZC5-at also has a high relative crystallinity, indicating that the alkaline treatment has only a slight impact on the microporous structure and the long-range ordering. FT-IR spectra (Fig. S2) further confirm that the prepared zeolite catalysts are the ZSM-5 crystal phase. SEM images ( Fig. 1) reflects that the concentration of NaOH in the synthesis gel has a great influence on the morphology and particle size of the resultant catalyst. The catalysts ZC1 to ZC4 are all composed of irregular aggregated particles. The sizes of the particles decrease gradually with increasing the concentration of NaOH in the synthesis gel. The particles in ZC1 and ZC2 are made up of the tightly stacked cuboid crystals. Intercrystalline mesopore can hardly be observed in the enlarged image (Fig. 1C). It’s worth noting that the particles in ZC3 are loose aggregates of nano crystals (Fig. 1D and E). Therefore, the abundant mesoporous structures are formed between the nano crystals (Fig. 1F). The size of an individual crystal becomes large and the observable mesopores disappear when further increasing the concentration of NaOH in the synthesis gel (Fig. 1G). As a result, the catalyst ZC5 displays a uniform coffin-shaped morphology with micron crystal size (Fig. 1H). In addition, Fig. 1G shows that there is little change in the morphology of the catalyst ZC5 after the alkaline treatment, further proving that the suitable treatment conditions will not cause excessive damage to the zeolite crystals. In order to study the pore structure accurately, the catalysts were characterised by N2 adsorption-desorption measurement. The results are shown in Fig. 2 and Table 1. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of ZC1 and ZC5 are of type I without distinct hysteresis loop (Fig. 2A), indicating the sole presence of microporosity [35]. However, the isotherms of ZC3 and ZC5-at exhibit both types I and IV behaviors, with the gradually increased slopes and the obvious hysteresis loops, suggesting the coexistence of micro- and mesoporosity [36]. The BJH pore size distribution curves (Fig. 2B) further demonstrate the presence of abundant mesopores in the catalysts ZC3 and ZC5-at. Especially for ZC3, the peak around 10 nm is remarkable. The results of the quantitative analysis of pore characteristics show that the catalysts ZC3 and ZC5-at possess similar external surface areas as well as mesopore volumes, significantly larger than the catalyst ZC1 or ZC5 (see Table 1). However, there are only slight differences in the microporous characteristics of all catalysts. Even after the alkaline treatment, the reduction in the micropore volume and the micropore area is fairly limited. The Ar adsorption-desorption measurements give similar results and further confirm the hierarchical structures were successfully constructed over the catalysts ZC3 and ZC5-at, as shown in Fig. S3 and Table S1. The morphology and pore structure of the prepared catalysts were also characterized by TEM. Fig. 3A further makes clear that the catalyst ZC3 has an abundant mesoporous structure resulting from the loose accumulation of nano crystals with the average diameter of about 20–50 nm. More importantly, these nano crystals are highly crystalline because they present very clear lattice fringes with different orientations, as shown in Fig. 3B. Fig. 3C further proves this result, which clearly exhibits the polycrystalline diffraction pattern of MFI framework [37]. As a contrast, the catalyst ZC5 displays the typical single crystal morphology with parallel lattice fringes spreading throughout the whole crystal (Fig. 3D and E). No mesoporous structure can be observed. The corresponding SAED pattern also indicates the single-crystalline nature of the crystal in ZC5 (Fig. 3F). After the alkaline treatment, the crystal morphology was well preserved in the catalyst ZC5-at (Fig. 3G), which is in good agreement with the SEM observation. However, the intracrystalline pore structure has changed dramatically. The plentiful string-like mesopores formed as interruptions of the lattice fringes can be observed at the crystal edges (Fig. 3H and I). These mesopores should result from the alkaline treatment. The results of XRF analysis (see Table 1) show that the content of residual Na in each catalyst is very low, no more than 0.2%. Furthermore, it can also be observed that an increase in the concentration of NaOH in the synthesis gel resulted in a reduction in the Si/Al ratio of the prepared catalyst and the alkali treatment caused the Si/Al ratio to become lower, which is in agreement with the previous reports [32]. Even so, the change of the Si/Al ratio is not very significant, range from 20.0 to 29.0. The 29Si MAS NMR analysis gives a similar result (Fig. S4 and Table S2). On the basis of the above mentioned results, we can draw a solid conclusion that the prepared catalysts ZC3 and ZC5-at have a hierarchical porous structure with abundant mesopores and micropores while the ZC5 is the conventional microporous zeolite, although they all belong to ZSM-5 zeolite phase. Then, the in-situ FTIR, 1H and 27Al MAS NMR spectroscopy were carried out on the prepared catalysts ZC3, ZC5 and ZC5-at to analyze and compare their framework defects. Fig. 4 shows the FTIR spectra of the dehydrated catalysts in the range 3800 − 3400 cm−1, which corresponds to the OH-stretching region [25]. There are five bands that need to be paid attention to in this range. The bands at 3745 cm−1, 3727 cm−1 and 3610 cm−1 are assigned to external silanol sites, silanols located in micropores and Brönsted acid sites, respectively [24]. In addition, two bands are closely correlated with the framework defects. One is the band at about 3665 cm−1 that can be ascribed to OH groups bound to extra-framework and/or perturbed framework Al species [29]. The other is the broad band around 3500 cm−1, which corresponds to silanol nests that generally occur at crystal steps or extended defects [24]. Compare with the catalyst ZC5-at, the ZC3 exhibits a significantly decreased band at 3665 cm−1. More importantly, the intensity of the broad band around 3500 cm−1 is lowest for the ZC3 among the three catalysts. These results indicate that the catalyst ZC3 has a lower content of defect sites than the ZC5 and ZC5-at. The 1H MAS NMR spectra ( Fig. 5A) of the dehydrated catalysts provide further evidence for the above conclusion. The peak at 1.7 ppm is assigned to the external silanol groups, while the one at 2.8 ppm can be attributed to the internal silanol groups which are associated with framework defects [27,38]. Obviously, the intensity of the peak centered at 2.8 ppm is lowest for the ZC3 among the three catalysts, indicating the lowest content of defects for the ZC3. Fig. 5B shows the 27Al MAS NMR spectra of the hydrated catalysts, in which two peaks can be observed. The major peak at about 55 ppm is attributed to the tetrahedrally coordinated Al atoms in the framework and the small peak around 0 ppm is assigned to the octahedrally coordinated extra-framework Al species which is closely associated with the framework defects [12]. It is obvious that the catalyst ZC5-at prepared by alkaline treatment presents an increased content of octahedral Al species relative to the parent catalyst ZC5, indicating that the alkaline treatment causes an increase in the content of defect sites. However, the catalyst ZC3 exhibits a significantly reduced intensity of the peak around 0 ppm compared with ZC5. The results further confirm that the catalyst ZC3 possesses a lowest content of defect sites among the three catalysts. There may be two reasons for this result. On the one hand, the introduction of mesoporosity without using secondary template and post-treatment technology can avoid the disturbance generated by the secondary template during crystallization and the destruction of the intrinsic structure of zeolite crystal during post-treatment [39,40]. Accordingly, the production of framework defects during the formation of mesopores was circumvented in this work. More importantly, it should be noted that the basicity of the synthesis system of the hierarchical catalyst ZC3 is lower than that of the conventional microporous catalyst ZC5. Recently, Valtchev et al. [41] reported that the number of defects in the zeolite framework had a correlation with the basicity of the synthesis system and the zeolite synthesized under a higher basicity exhibited a larger number of framework defects. Therefore, the synthesis method used here can realize the reduction of framework defects when creating mesopores. Another advantage of the synthesis method used here is the high product yield of the catalyst. The product yield of the catalyst ZC5-at is only 70.9%. However, The product yields of the catalysts ZC1 to ZC5 are all exceed 90%, such as 93.2% of ZC3 and 91.6% of ZC5. The high product yield means the great application potential in industry. 3.2 Catalytic properties of hierarchical zeolite catalysts in MTH reaction The stability of the prepared catalysts in the MTH reaction was measured in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor. Fig. 6A shows the change of the conversion of methanol with time-on-stream over different catalysts. The hollow symbols represent the experimental data and the solid lines indicate the fitting curves obtained using the deactivation model proposed by Janssens [34]. It is very clear that the hierarchical catalyst ZC3 exhibited the best catalytic stability while the microporous catalyst ZC5 presented the most rapid deactivation. It is worth noting that although the catalyst ZC5-at possesses similar mesoporous characteristics to ZC3 (as shown in Table 1), its stability is not improved significantly. A quantitative comparison was made based on the calculated values of rate constant (κ), deactivation coefficient (α), lifetime (t1/2) and conversion capacity (R0) according to the deactivation model proposed by Janssens [34], as shown in Table 2. Remarkably, the lifetime as well as the methanol conversion capacity of the hierarchical catalyst ZC3 is improved by 7.1 times compared with the microporous catalyst ZC5. However, the hierarchical catalyst ZC5-at only exhibited an improvement of 1.4 times. It has been reported that the acid concentration is one of the important factors affecting the MTH catalytic lifetime for zeolite catalyst [42]. Thus, the acidic properties of the prepared catalysts were characterized by NH3-TPD analysis. The results are presented in Fig. S5 and Table S3. The change in the acid concentrations follows the same trend as it in the Si/Al ratios (see Table 1). Even so, there is no obvious correlation between the catalytic lifetimes and the concentration of total acid sites as well as strong acid sites, as shown in Fig. S6. These results indicate that the acid concentration is not a dominant factor influencing the catalytic lifetime here. In order to further prove the inference, a dealuminated catalyst was prepared based on ZC5 using the approach reported by Yuan et al. [43] and denoted as ZC5-deAl. The results of characterizations and catalytic test are shown in Fig. S7 and Table S4. Compared with the catalyst ZC3, the the catalyst ZC5-deAl exhibits a similar mesoporosity and a lower acid concentration but its catalytic lifetime (t1/2) is still very short (14.4 h vs. 41.8 h), further reflecting that the acid concentration is not a key factor in this work. Then, a relation diagram between the catalytic lifetimes and the external surface areas is built to study the mesoporous effect, as shown in Fig. 6B. Interestingly, a good linear correlation can be observed within the range of the catalysts prepared without alkali treatment. However, the catalyst ZC5-at does not meet the correlation, as marked by the red arrow in Fig. 6B. Considering the results of Figs. 4 and 5, the high content of the defect sites ZC5-at possessed should account for this special case. Concretely speaking, the framework defects in zeolite catalyst can facilitate the formation of coke precursors while the hierarchical porous structure is beneficial to their diffusion [29]. If the framework defects are rich, the positive effect coming from hierarchical pores will be offset because the fast formation of coke precursors will increase the difficulty of diffusion. This situation should occur over the catalyst ZC5-at. In order to prove this inference, the initial product selectivities were compared over the different catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7A. For the catalysts prepared without alkali treatment, the main products are light hydrocarbons with the carbon number less than 5. However, the catalyst ZC5-at exhibited a very high selectivity for C6 + components, exceed 80%. At present, the dual-cycle mechanism is widely accepted for the MTH reaction over the ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst [13]. Two cycles are involved in this mechanism. One is the olefin-based cycle, in which propylene is the main product [12]. The other is the aromatic-based cycle that is responsible for the formation of ethylene and aromatics [42]. The results of Fig. 7A indicate that the aromatic-based cycle should be promoted significantly over the catalyst ZC5-at. According to the literatures [12], the ratio of propene to ethane can also be used as an indicator to represent the relative contribution of the two cycles. Fig. 7B shows the ratios of propene to ethane in the initial products over different catalysts. As expected, ZC5-at presents the lowest ratio among the five catalysts, which further demonstrates that the contribution of aromatic-based cycle over ZC5-at is higher than other catalysts. It should be mentioned that the coke precursors in the MTH reaction, such as methylated benzenes, usually come from the aromatic-based cycle rather than the olefin-based cycle [13]. That is, the more dominant the aromatic-based cycle becomes, the faster the coke precursors are generated. Thus, the formation of coke precursors over the catalyst ZC5-at should be faster than other catalysts. However, the catalyst ZC3 shows the highest ratio of propene to ethane and very high selectivity towards light olefins, indicating the aromatic-based cycle was suppressed. The only marked structural difference between ZC5-at and ZC3 is that the latter possesses the notably decreased framework defects (see Figs. 4 and 5), other structural parameters, such as mesoporosity and microporosity, are all similar. This means that the aromatic-based cycle as well as the formation of coke precursors can be effectively suppressed through the removal of defect sites in zeolite catalyst, which is in agreement with the previous reports [24,27,29]. To obtain deeper insight into the effect of mesoporosity and framework defects on the formation of coke, the used catalysts were characterized by TGA and N2 adsorption-desorption. The results are shown in Fig. 8, Figs. S8 and S9. The total coke amounts (TC) drived from the TG curves decrease in the order of ZC3 > ZC5-at > ZC5, as shown in Table 2. Although the more coke was deposited on the catalyst ZC3, it presents higher conversion relative to ZC5. This result indicates that the hierarchical catalyst possesses higher ability to resist coke than the microporous catalyst. The average rate of coke deposition was calculated by dividing the total coke amount by the reaction time. It is notabe that the catalyst ZC3 presented a significantly slower rate of coke deposition than ZC5 and ZC5-at. For comparison, the coke deposition over ZC5-at is fastest among the three catalysts. This difference means that the framework defects should have a greater effect on the rate of coke deposition, compared to the pore structure [29]. In addition, the indistinctive correlation between the acid concentration and the amount of coke (Fig. S10) indicates that the acid concentration is not a dominant factor influencing the coke deposition in this work. The information about coke locations (i.e. contents of internal and external cokes) in the three catalysts is obtained according to the formulas proposed by Choi et al. [13] and shown in Fig. 9. As expected, the hierarchical catalyst ZC3 as well as ZC5-at exhibited a higher ratio of external to internal coke than the microporous catalyst ZC5. In this regard, the hierarchical porous structure should promote the diffusion of coke precursors out of the micropores [33]. What’s interesting is that the proportion of external coke over the catalyst ZC3 is obviously greater than that over ZC5-at, suggesting that the diffusion of coke precursors may be indirectly affected by the framework defects. A rational explanation is that the high content of framework defects led to the rapid formation of coke precursors in the micropores and a lot of coke precursors generated within a short time can obviously increase the difficulty of diffusion. The coke precursors that can’t diffuse out of the micropores in time will develop into the internal coke deposition easily [44]. As a result, more internal coke was deposited on the catalyst ZC5-at. Considering that the internal coke deposits can cause a much more serious deactivation than external coke [13], the shorter catalytic lifetime of ZC5-at compared with ZC3 is reasonable. On the contrary, for the hierarchical catalyst ZC3, the low content of defect sites suppressed the generation of coke precursors from the beginning [29]. Moreover, the presence of mesoporosity enabled the rapid diffusion of coke precursors out of the zeolite micropores [45]. Thus, it exhibited a remarkably enhanced catalytic lifetime. 4 Conclusion In this work, a hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite with low defect density was successfully synthesized by a simple one-step method without using secondary template and fluoride media. The resultant hierarchical zeolite catalyst is composed of loose aggregates of nano crystals and presents the mesoporosity similar to the alkaline-treated zeolite catalyst. More importantly, it possesses a lower content of framework defects than the conventional microporous zeolite catalyst as well as the alkaline-treated zeolite catalyst. In the MTH reaction, the low defect density suppressed the generation of coke precursors and the hierarchical pore structure facilitated the diffusion of coke precursors out of the zeolite micropores. Thus, the prepared hierarchical zeolite catalyst exhibited a very slow rate of coke deposition and a significantly prolonged catalytic lifetime. The achieved catalyst material together with the simple synthesis strategy can provide value information for constructing other long-lived catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The combination of introducing mesopores and minimizing framework defects in zeolite catalysts has been proved to be highly effective in improving their catalytic lifetime in the MTH reaction. However, there is currently a lack of simple method to realize these two purposes at the same time. In this work, we report a simple one-step approach which not only completed the introduction of abundant mesopores into zeolite catalyst but also simultaneously realized the reduction of framework defects. Secondary template, fluoride media and post-treatment technology were not used during the synthetic process. As an example, a hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst with low defect density was successfully synthesized. In the MTH reaction, the synergy effect of the hierarchical pore structure and the less framework defects endowed the prepared zeolite catalyst with a very long lifetime, which is 7.1 times that of the reference catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: One-step synthesis of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolites with low defect density as long-lived MTH catalysts
